chapter.title: Installing &caasp; &o_orch; Templates
chapter.para: This chapter describes how to install &caasp; &o_orch; template on &productname;.

section.title: &caasp; &o_orch; Installation Procedure

step.para: Download the latest &caasp; for &ostack; image (for example, SUSE-CaaS-Platform-3.0-OpenStack-Cloud.x86_64-1.0.0-GM.qcow2) from .
Upload the image to &o_img;:
step.screen: openstack image create --public --disk-format qcow2 --container-format \ bare --file SUSE-CaaS-Platform-3.0-OpenStack-Cloud.x86_64-1.0.0-GM.qcow2 \ CaaSP-3

step.para: Install the caasp-openstack-heat-templates package on a machine with &productname; repositories:
The installed templates are located in /usr/share/caasp-openstack-heat-templates.
Alternatively, you can get official &o_orch; templates by cloning the appropriate Git repository:
In &o_dash;, go to ProjectStacksLaunch Stack.
Select File from the Template Source drop-down box and upload the caasp-stack.yaml file.
In the Launch Stack dialog, provide the required information (stack name, password, flavor size, external network of your environment, etc.).

Click Launch to launch the stack. This creates all required resources for running &caasp; in an &ostack; environment. The stack creates one &admnode;, one &masternode;, and server worker nodes as specified.

procedure.title: Install Templates from the Command Line

step.para: Specify the appropriate flavor and network settings in the caasp-environment.yaml file.
Create a stack in &o_orch; by passing the template, environment file, and parameters:
step.screen: openstack stack create -t caasp-stack.yaml -e caasp-environment.yaml \ --parameter image=CaaSP-3 caasp-stack

step.para: After the stack has been created, the &caasp_dash; runs on the &admnode;. You can access it using the &admnode;'s floating IP address.
Create an account and follow the steps in the &caasp_dash; to complete the &caasp; installation.

section.para: When you have successfully accessed the admin node web interface via the floating IP, follow the instructions at to continue the setup of &caasp;.

section.title: Installing &caasp; with Multiple Masters

note.para: A &o_orch; stack with load balancing and multiple master nodes can only be created from the command line, because &o_dash; does not have support for nested &o_orch; templates.

section.para: Install the caasp-openstack-heat-templates package on a machine with &productname; repositories:
The installed templates are located in /usr/share/caasp-openstack-heat-templates.
A working load balancer is needed in your &cloud; deployment. &productname; uses HAProxy.
Verify that load balancing with HAProxy is working correctly in your &ostack; installation by creating a load balancer manually and checking that the provisioning_status changes to Active.
HAProxy is the default load balancer provider in &productname;.
The steps below can be used to set up a network, subnet, router, security and IPs for a test lb_net1 network with lb_subnet1 subnet.
section.screen: &prompt.ardana;openstack network create lb_net1 &prompt.ardana;openstack subnet create --name lb_subnet1 lb_net1 \ --subnet-range 172.29.0.0/24 --gateway 172.29.0.2 &prompt.ardana;openstack router create lb_router1 &prompt.ardana;openstack router add subnet lb_router1 lb_subnet1 &prompt.ardana;openstack router set lb_router1 --external-gateway ext-net &prompt.ardana;openstack network list

procedure.title: Steps to Install &caasp; with Multiple Masters

step.para: Specify the appropriate flavor and network settings in the caasp-multi-master-environment.yaml file.
Set master_count to the desired number in the caasp-multi-master-environment.yaml file. The master count must be set to an odd number of nodes.
Create a stack in &o_orch; by passing the template, environment file, and parameters:
step.screen: &prompt.ardana;openstack stack create -t caasp-multi-master-stack.yaml \ -e caasp-multi-master-environment.yaml --parameter image=CaaSP-3 caasp-multi-master-stack

step.para: Find the floating IP address of the load balancer. This is necessary for accessing the Velum &caasp; dashboard.
From the output, copy the id and enter it in the following command as shown in the following example:
Search the floating IP list for vip_address
step.screen: &prompt.ardana;openstack floating ip list | grep 172.28.0.6 | d636f3...481b0c | fd7ff...deb4c1 | 172.28.0.6 | 10.84.65.37 | 53ad2...373e8b |

step.para: The load balancer floating ip address is 10.84.65.37

section.para: After the stack has been created, the Velum &caasp; dashboard runs on the admin node. You can access it using the floating IP address of the admin node.
Create an account and follow the steps in the Velum &caasp; dashboard to complete the &caasp; installation.
&caasp; Admin Node Install: Screen 1
If you plan to manage your containers using Helm or Airship (this is common), check the box labeled Install Tiller (Helm's server component).

&caasp; Admin Node Install: Screen 5
Set External Kubernetes API to LOADBALANCER_FLOATING_IP, External Dashboard FQDN to ADMIN_NODE_FLOATING_IP
&caasp; Admin Node Install: Screen 6
&caasp; Admin Node Install: Screen 7

step.para: Install the caasp-openstack-heat-templates package on a machine with &productname; repositories:
The installed templates are located in /usr/share/caasp-openstack-heat-templates.
Run heat-caasp-deploy.yml on the &clm; to create a &caasp; cluster with &o_orch; templates from the caasp-openstack-heat-templates package.
In a browser, navigate to the &o_dash; UI to determine the floating IP address assigned to the admin node.
Go to http://ADMIN-NODE-FLOATING-IP/ to bring up the Velum dashboard.
Follow the steps for bootstrap and add nodes to the cluster to bring up the &caasp; Kubernetes cluster.

section.title: Enabling the Cloud Provider Integration (CPI) Feature
section.para: When deploying a CaaaSP cluster using &caasp; &ostack; &o_orch; templates, the following CPI parameters can be set in caasp-environment.yaml or caasp-multi-master-environment.yaml.

listitem.para: The URL of the &o_ident; API used to authenticate the user. This value can be found on &ostack; Dashboard under Access and SecurityAPI AccessCredentials (for example, https://api.keystone.example.net:5000/)
Name of the domain the user belongs to
Name of the project the user belongs to. This is the project where the resources will be created.
Name of the region to use when running a multi-region &ostack; cloud. The region is a general division of an &ostack; deployment.
Username of a valid user that has been set in &o_ident;. Default: admin
Password of a valid user that has been set in &o_ident;.
&o_netw; load balancer monitoring max retries. Default: 3
&o_blockstore; Block Storage API version. Possible values are v1, v2 , v3 or auto. Default: auto
Ignore &o_blockstore; and &o_comp; availability zones. Default: true
Set this to the IP address of a DNS nameserver accessible by the &caasp; cluster.

section.para: When the &caasp; cluster has been deployed by the &o_orch; templates, the Velum dashboard on the admin node (https://ADMIN-NODE-IP/) will have entries for Cloud Provider Integration (CPI). The &ostack; settings form will show the values that were set in the caasp-environment.yaml or caasp-multi-master-environment.yaml files.
After the &caasp; cluster comes up, install the latest &caasp; 3.0 Maintenance Update using the following steps:

step.para: Spin up a &caasp; cluster using &o_orch; templates following the instructions in . Do not go through the bootstrapping steps, because the &caasp; Maintenance Update (MU) must be applied first. After the maintenance update process below succeeds, return to the &caasp; installation instructions and follow the admin node bootstrapping steps.

Apply the &caasp; 3.0 Maintenance Update with the following steps by running them on each node in the cluster. This can be done one at a time, or in parallel, but must be performed as the root user. The openstack server list command will display the list of &caasp; nodes with their IP addresses, and the default password to access the root account via SSH is linux.
Add the update repository.

Because nu.novell.com must be reachable in order to proceed with the update, external network access and name resolution via the DNS server you specifed in the dns_nameserver parameter must be functioning correctly at this time. Confirm this by running:
Install the update:
Verify that the Velum image packages were updated:
step.screen: zypper se --detail velum-image i | sles12-velum-image | package | 3.1.7-3.27.3 | x86_64 | update_caasp

step.para: Reboot the node:

When preparing to bootstrap using the &caasp; web interface, set the Internal Dashboard Location to the private network IP address (i.e. in the the 172.x.x.x subnet) of the &caasp; admin node created during the heat-caasp-deploy.yml playbook. Do not use the floating IP address which may appear by default in the field.

Upload a valid trust certificate that can validate a certificate presented by &o_ident; at the specified keystone_auth_url in the System-wide certificate section of Velum. The certificate must be uploaded to avoid bootstrapping failure with a x509: certificate signed by unknown authority error message.
Get SUSE Root CA certificate with the following steps:
From the RPM provided in the repos:
Add a repository for your distribution at http://download.suse.de/ibs/SUSE:/CA/. For example, with openSUSE Leap, use http://download.suse.de/ibs/SUSE:/CA/openSUSE_Leap_15.0/SUSE:CA.repo
Install certificates and find the .pem file.
The path to the cert is /usr/share/pki/trust/anchors/SUSE_Trust_Root.crt.pem
In system wide certificate during setup in Velum, upload this certificate so you can bootstrap with CPI.
After the nodes come up, continue with the installation instructions in following the admin node cluster bootstrapping steps.
